questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, recurrent headaches, and anorexia. One month ago, she returned from a camping trip in Chile. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows a swelling in the left periorbital region and axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. A blood sample is obtained. Processing of the sample with which of the following methods is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staining with crystal violet dyes (e.g., Gram stain) is the standard approach for identifying and classifying bacteria in a specimen. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), and Gram stain would be useful for excluding a bacterial cause, her unilateral periorbital swelling in particular warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease, which is caused by a protozoan.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycolic acid staining (e.g. Ziehl-Neelsen stain) is used to identify acid-fast organisms such as mycobacteria. Tuberculosis (TB) can present with a myriad of symptoms, including those seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy). However, her unilateral periorbital swelling warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease instead.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

C) INCORRECT:

India ink staining is used to identify the thick polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans, which most typically causes pneumonia and meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised patients. Although this patient does have symptoms indicating some type of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), disseminated lymphadenopathy and unilateral periorbital swelling after travel abroad is not consistent with C. neoformans infection in a previously healthy patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

D) CORRECT:

Chagas disease is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted by inoculation of fecal material of the triatomine reduvid bug into skin or mucous membranes. The reduvid bug preferentially bites on the face (“kissing bug”). The Romana sign occurs when the portal of entry of T. cruzi is the conjunctiva or eyelid. The pathogen subsequently disseminates via the bloodstream. Staining this patient's peripheral blood with stains that contain aniline dyes (e.g, Giemsa stain, Wright stain) would likely reveal the presence of Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes. Treatment with benznidazole or nifurtimox is necessary to prevent complications of Chagas disease such as dilated cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus, and acute megacolon.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

E) INCORRECT:

Glycogen staining methods, such as in periodic acid-Schiff stains, are useful in diagnosing Whipple disease. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), she does not have the enteropathic arthritis, neurological symptoms, or chronic diarrhea and insidious malabsorption typical for Whipple disease. Rather, her unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph (very high magnification, Periodic acid-Schiff stain) of a duodenal biopsy

Within the cytoplasm of the macrophages, granular PAS-positive material is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of Whipple disease, which is caused by Tropheryma whippleii.

F) INCORRECT:

Silver staining is useful for identifying fungi (e.g., Coccidioides) as well as some bacteria (e.g., H. pylori, Legionella pneumophila). Legionella pneumophila infection (legionellosis) could cause the nonspecific features seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy) but it would also cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough) or GI symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea), which are not reported by this patient. Unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease, which cannot be diagnosed by silver stain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

G) INCORRECT:

A stain that reacts with iron (Prussian blue stain) is used to identify iron deposits (e.g., hemosiderin in hemochromatosis, ferruginous bodies in asbestosis, marrow sideroblasts in sideroblastic anemia). This patient has features of an infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy). Stains containing iron (e.g, colloidal iron stain, iron-hematoxylin trichome stain) can be used to stain pathogens that are rich in mucopolysaccharides but stains that react with iron are rarely used in clinical microbiology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample (Prussian blue stain)

Prussian blue stains the iron deposits dark blue (green arrows) and the nuclei bright red. A portal triad (P; green overlay) is visible in the lower left corner.
questions.hint: This patient traveled to an area where Chagas disease is endemic (Central and South America) and now presents with features of infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy) and unilateral periorbital swelling (Romana sign), which are very characteristic of acute Chagas disease.

questions.text: An investigator studying targeted therapy in patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors requires a reliable test to determine the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens. Which of the following is the most appropriate test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is a technique that allows identification, quantification, and sorting of single cells via an antigen-antibody mediated binding of a fluorescent tag. This technique requires suspension of cells within a liquid medium, so it is ideal for evaluation of hematologic samples, rather than the solid tumors in this experiment. In solid tumors, disaggregation of tissue to allow single cell suspension is very difficult and does not allow evaluation of tissue architecture.
Image Description:

Flow cytometry with fluorescent-tagged antibodies was used to differentiate lymphocyte populations. Each point in the image represents a labeled B or T lymphocyte.

The T cell scatter plot shows a high concentration of CD8+ T cells (upper left quadrant), which is consistent with the immune-mediated reaction of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells against EBV infected B lymphocytes seen in infectious mononucleosis.

T cell plot:
Upper left quadrant: cells that are CD4- and CD8+
Upper right quadrant: cells that CD4+ and CD8+
Lower left quadrant: cells that are CD4- and CD8-
Lower right quadrant: cells that are CD4+ and CD8-

B) CORRECT:

Immunohistochemistry uses antigen-antibody interactions to identify a specific cell or tissue based on the presence or absence of a certain antigen. In this study, the CD117 (c-KIT) serves as an antigen that characterizes GIST cells. An anti-CD117-antibody that is coupled with a chromogenic substrate will bind on the cell surface and visualize the tumor cells using ordinary light microscopy. This technique is best for studying special cell populations within biopsy samples due to the preservation of tissue architecture.
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

A Western blot is a form of gel electrophoresis that allows identification of proteins/antigens based on antigen-antibody binding. Although the use of this technique will identify all CD117 antigens, the preparation of media for gel electrophoresis requires destruction and lysis of cells to create a lysate. Therefore, Western blot is not the method of choice to determine the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in a biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

A Northern blot is a form of gel electrophoresis that allows the study of tissues based on the detection of RNA molecules. This investigator, however, is interested in studying the expression of CD117 marker in GIST tumors, and so is examining a cell surface protein.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) allows for direct visualization/detection of DNA molecules by using a probe that binds to specific genomic sequences. This investigator, however, is interested in studying the expression of CD117 marker in GIST tumors, and so is examining a cell surface protein.
Image Description:

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) can be used for chromosome analysis. The example shown here involves chromosomes during metaphase.

(1) Chromosomes are prepared and DNA is denatured into single strands. DNA probes are added that are complementary to the DNA segment and bind specifically to it (hybridization). (2) The DNA probe can be directly labeled (direct staining, 2) or chemically modified (3a), which requires the addition of a fluorescent-labeled antibody for detection (indirect staining, 3b). The fluorescent-labeled chromosome (segments) can be examined using a microscope (4).
questions.hint: CD markers are proteins, which can act as antigens on the surface of cells.

questions.text: A pathologist receives a patient sample for analysis. Cells in the sample are first labeled with fluorescent antibodies and then passed across a laser beam in a single file of particles. The light scatter and fluorescent intensity of the particles are plotted on a graph; this information is used to characterize the sample. This laboratory method would be most useful to establish the diagnosis of a patient with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) can present with pancytopenia, deep vein thrombosis, and intermittent hemoglobinuria. It usually results from impaired synthesis of the glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchor (GPI), which links cell surface proteins like CD55 and CD59 to the plasma membrane. These surface proteins are inhibitors of complement activation; their absence permits inappropriate complement-mediated destruction of cells. Flow cytometry is used to detect the reduced expression of CD55 and CD59 on RBCs and confirm the diagnosis of PNH.

B) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome presents with cleft palate, hypoplastic thymus (leading to low T-lymphocyte count), conotruncal abnormalities (e.g., ventricular septal defects), and hypocalcemia (from aplastic parathyroid glands) due to aberrant development of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. It is caused by chromosomal microdeletion at 22q11.2, which can be detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). Flow cytometry has no role in detecting chromosomal abnormalities

C) INCORRECT:

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection lowers the CD4+ T-cell count rendering individuals susceptible to multiple opportunistic infections. HIV diagnosis is made using combined antigen/antibody immunoassay, which has close to 100% sensitivity and specificity in patients with chronic infection. When the first test turns out positive, a confirmatory test (HIV-1/HIV-2 differentiation immunoassay) that identifies the different subtypes of the virus will be conducted. Even though flow cytometry can be used to quantify the CD4+ T-cell count, it has no role in establishing the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which is caused by reactivation of varicella-zoster virus within the trigeminal ganglion, manifests with vesicular lesions in a dermatomal distribution and dendritic corneal ulcers. VZV infections can be confirmed by detecting the viral DNA using polymerase chain reaction (PCR), which amplifies the target DNA using heat-resistant DNA polymerase, deoxynucleotide triphosphates, DNA primers complementary to the target DNA, and a buffer solution that mediates optimal enzymatic reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma presents with rapidly growing jaw mass in endemic cases (accounting for 50–60% of cases) and painless generalized lymphadenopathy with involvement of the bone marrow and central nervous system when associated with immunodeficiency. Diagnosis is made through histologic analysis of the biopsied tissue, which shows monomorphic cells with interspersed benign histiocytes, giving rise to a "starry sky" appearance. Although flow cytometry can be used to help characterize non-Hodgkin lymphomas, it alone cannot confirm this diagnosis.
questions.hint: The process described above is the procedure of flow cytometry, which is a laboratory technique used to count/sort cells after immunolabeling the antigen of interest.

questions.text: A medical technician is trying to isolate a pathogen from the sputum sample of a patient. The sample is heat fixed to a slide then covered with carbol fuchsin stain and heated again. After washing off the stain with clean water, the slide is covered with sulfuric acid. The sample is rinsed again and stained with methylene blue. Microscopic examination shows numerous red organisms. Which of the following is the most likely isolated pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei can be identified using periodic acid-Schiff staining, not carbol fuchsin. Periodic acid-Schiff stains glycogen and mucopolysaccharides blue, and it can be used to detect PAS-positive macrophages in the diagnosis of Whipple disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Rickettsia rickettsii can be identified using Giemsa staining, not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using Giemsa staining include Borrelia, Chlamydia, and Plasmodia.

C) CORRECT:

Nocardia asteroides is a weakly acid-fast organism that partially retains carbol fuchsin stain after it is rinsed with sulfuric acid. Other important acid-fast organisms that stain positive with Ziehl-Neelsen staining include mycobacteria (e.g., M. tuberculosis) and the oocysts of Cryptosporidium and Isospora. Acid-fast bacteria can also be identified using Kinyoun stain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans can be identified using India ink staining, mucicarmine staining, or silver staining, but not carbol fuchsin. The polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans appears as a halo around the organism when India ink staining is applied. When mucicarmine staining is used, the polysaccharide capsule appears red.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori can be identified using Giemsa staining or silver staining, but not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using silver staining include Legionella, Pseudomonas, and Pneumocystis jirovecii.

F) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma cruzi can be identified using Giemsa staining, not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using Giemsa staining include Borrelia, Chlamydia, and Plasmodia.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

G) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus can be identified using Gram staining, in which crystal violet dye is first applied to the specimen, followed by a safranin counterstain. Although carbol fuchsin can be used as a counterstain, safranin is much more commonly used. Furthermore, no crystal violet dyes were used on the sample.
questions.hint: The procedure (Ziehl-Neelsen staining) described is used to identify organisms with mycolic acid in their cell walls.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, unintentional weight loss, and mild hemoptysis for two weeks. He has a 35-year smoking history and reports no fevers or night sweats. Breath sounds are decreased over the right upper lung field (see reports).

Chest X-ray: 3-cm right upper lobe mass
Sputum cytology: Inconclusive
PET scan: Increased uptake in the right upper lobe

Which of the following is required to definitively confirm a diagnosis of cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Histopathologic examination of a tissue sample is essential for confirming cancer, as it allows direct evaluation of cellular morphology and architecture to identify malignant features. Tissue can be obtained through bronchoscopic, CT-guided, or surgical biopsy. This process not only confirms malignancy but also aids in tumor subtyping and grading, crucial for prognosis and management. Microscopic evaluation enables the use of ancillary techniques like immunohistochemistry and molecular profiling, refining diagnosis and informing targeted therapy.

Key learning point: Tissue histopathology is the definitive method for diagnosing cancer, as it involves microscopic examination of tissue samples to confirm the presence of cancer cells.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI offers excellent soft tissue resolution but cannot provide the histological material needed for a definitive cancer diagnosis. Imaging studies, including MRI, cannot distinguish between benign and malignant pathology. Tissue biopsy is necessary for histopathological confirmation.

C) INCORRECT:

Sputum cytology has lower sensitivity than tissue biopsy for diagnosing lung cancer. Inconclusive initial results, especially with a 3-cm mass showing high PET uptake, make repeating the test unlikely to provide a definitive diagnosis. Sputum cytology is more effective for centrally located tumors, not solitary upper lobe masses.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum tumor markers lack the sensitivity and specificity needed to confirm lung cancer. They do not provide histological details and can be influenced by benign conditions. A definitive diagnosis requires tissue sampling for histopathological examination and molecular analysis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of persistent cough, hemoptysis, night sweats, and a 3-kg weight loss to the clinic. He recently emigrated from a region with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. He reports occasional chills and a recent positive PPD skin test performed abroad. Examination shows diminished breath sounds in the right upper lobe (see report).


Respiratory rate
22/min


Temperature
37.8 °C


Chest X-ray: Cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe
Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to confirm infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis?

choices.text: Serologic assay for Mycobacterium tuberculosis antibodies
Gram stain of sputum followed by culture on blood agar
Microscopic sputum smear with acid-fast staining

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serologic assays detect antibodies against Mycobacterium tuberculosis but have limitations in sensitivity and specificity. They may yield false positives due to cross-reactivity and cannot reliably distinguish between latent and active disease. Direct detection methods, such as acid-fast bacilli smear or nucleic acid amplification tests, are more definitive for active infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis has a lipid-rich cell wall that resists Gram staining, requiring acid-fast stains for visualization. It also requires specialized culture media, like Lowenstein-Jensen agar, for growth. Blood agar is not suitable for detecting or culturing M. tuberculosis, leading to false-negative results.

C) CORRECT:

The acid-fast stain is essential for identifying Mycobacterium tuberculosis in respiratory specimens due to its lipid-rich cell wall, which resists decolorization with acid alcohol. This method, typically performed on multiple sputum samples, allows visualization of acid-fast bacilli, confirming active pulmonary tuberculosis. The patient's symptoms, such as chronic cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and cavitary lesions on chest x-ray, along with a positive tuberculin skin test, support the use of this test for confirming mycobacterial infection. Rapid detection through acid-fast staining aids in timely management of suspected active tuberculosis.

Key learning point: Ziehl-Neelsen stain is the standard diagnostic test for identifying acid-fast bacilli, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, in suspected cases of pulmonary tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The tuberculin skin test indicates prior sensitization to Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens but does not confirm active disease. It cannot distinguish between latent infection and active replication. Additionally, prior Bacille Calmette-Guérin vaccination and exposure to non-tuberculous mycobacteria can affect its specificity. Direct microbiological tests are necessary for confirming active tuberculosis.
